episodes.title: They Vowed To Give Their Lives... Literally
episodes.description:
Join Megan Conner and Kirsten as they dive into the shocking and bizarre doctrine of bl00d atonement in the LDS Church! As ex-mormons, we're unpacking this wild Mormon belief where certain sins—like RedRum or apostasy—supposedly require your own bl00d to be spilled for true forgiveness, beyond Jesus' atonement. From Brigham Young's teachings to its roots in early Mormon history, we'll explore how this creepy concept shaped LDS theology and why it's one of the church's most controversial secrets. If you're questioning Mormonism, leaving the LDS faith, or just curious about exmormon stories, this video exposes the dark side of Mormon doctrine with snark and facts. Join the Exmormon Snark community for more eye-opening revelations on LDS church history, exmormon experiences, and deconstructing Mormon beliefs.   


 #exmormon #BloodAtonement #LDSChurch #MormonHistory #Exmo #MormonDoctrine #LDSsecrets #DeconstructingMormonism #ExmormonStories #BrighamYoung #MormonBeliefs #FaithTransition #PostMormon

episodes.title: Nothing Says "Faithful Mormon" Like Severing Some Arms...
episodes.description:
Kirsten and Megan Discuss growing up LDS with their Mormon Cartoon book from 1978. 
In the Book of Mormon, there are many stories about war and justifiable vigilante justice. 

Ever read the Book of Mormon story where violence is somehow framed as spiritual leadership? Let’s talk about Ammon, the missionary who cuts off a bunch of arms to impress King Lamoni and somehow ends up being the gold standard for faith, obedience, and righteousness.

In this video, we break down one of the wildest Book of Mormon stories—where extreme violence is rewarded, shock value equals conversion, and nobody seems bothered by the pile of severed arms. Why was this story taught to us as inspirational? Why were we expected to admire it? And why does it feel more like ancient propaganda than divine morality?

If you were raised Mormon, ex-Mormon, or are just fascinated by religious stories that don’t age well, this one’s for you. Snark included. Critical thinking encouraged. Arms… definitely unnecessary.

🎥 Watch as we unpack:
 • The Ammon arm-cutting story
 • Why violence = righteousness in Mormon scripture
 • How shock tactics were framed as “faith-building”
 • Why this story hits VERY differently once you’re out

⸻

Book of Mormon, Ammon cuts off arms, King Lamoni, Lamanites, Mormon scripture, LDS church history, ex Mormon commentary, Mormon stories explained, problematic Bible stories, religious trauma, deconstruction, ex mormon comedy, ex mormon humor, family home evening, mormon stories, Book of Mormon

#ExMormon #BookOfMormon #MormonHistory #Deconstruction #ReligiousTrauma #MormonStories #ExMoTikTok #FaithCrisis #CultRecovery #Snark #LDSChurch

episodes.title: What is An LDS Patriarchal Blessing?
episodes.description:
Back in the beginning of the LDS church, Joseph Smith appointed his father "Patriarch" over the church. Joe Sr. Charged anywhere from $1 to $5 to give people a special blessing, which was supposed to help them get a peek into the future. This practice later evolved into a sort of 'roadmap', with leaders encouraging youth as young as 12 to get their Patriarchal Blessing as a guide to future decision making. 

Patriarchal blessings are supposed to be deeply personal, divinely inspired roadmaps for your life—but what happens when you actually read them years later?

In this video, we share and discuss our own Mormon patriarchal blessings and unpack how they were framed as sacred guidance, yet ended up being vague, manipulative, and strangely interchangeable. We talk about how these blessings often rely on ambiguity, conditional promises, and fear-based obedience—while convincing members that they are uniquely chosen and personally known by God.

We explore how patriarchal blessings can:
 • Feel incredibly specific at first… until you compare them
 • Place responsibility on the individual when “promises” don’t come true
 • Reinforce obedience, conformity, and authority
 • Create pressure, guilt, and self-blame instead of clarity

If you’ve ever wondered why your patriarchal blessing didn’t actually guide your life—or why it somehow made you feel like you were the problem—this conversation is for you.

Whether you’re ex-Mormon, questioning, or just curious about high-demand religions, this video dives into the psychology behind why patriarchal blessings feel powerful… and why that power fades once you step back and look critically.

💬 Share in the comments: Did your patriarchal blessing come true? Or was it vague enough to mean anything?

⸻

episodes.title: The Super Top Secret Mormon Temple Ceremony Nobody Talks About
episodes.description:
Just when you though mormonism couldn't get any weirder... The LDS church has ANOTHER super top secret temple ceremony. But this one, even faithful members don't know about. 

In this ceremony, top leaders of the Church Of Jesus Christ (of Latter-Day Saints) get promised that no matter what they do (except one thing) they will get into the top tier of Mormon heaven.  

In the LDS temple on Sunday afternoons, you might catch a glimpse of mormons in the "in" crowd gathering for a ceremony that is nicknamed "Having Your Calling and Election Made Sure" ... then you can do no wrong in the eyes of mormon god.

episodes.title: This Mormon Temple Ceremony Required Me To Be N00d
episodes.description:
There is a Mormon temple ceremony called the 'Initiatory' ceremony. This ceremony is performed before the main "Endowment Ceremony". Before putting on the temple garment (magic undies), temple patrons were required (prior to 2015) to be nude under a poncho (with the sides open) for this 'washing and annointing' ceremony. This was Megan's experience. She was totally unprepared for this, because Mormons believe the temple ceremonies to be too 'sacred' to talk about outside of the temple. ***Discussion of the ceremony starts around 55 min***

We want informed consent for LDS Temple Ceremonies! 

*** The full text of the Mormon Temple Ceremony is repeated in this episode***  
(Initiatory only)

Join us at THIRVE St. George! 
https://thrivebeyondreligion.com/event/st-george-thrive-2026/

episodes.title: How LDS Leaders tricked Mormons
episodes.description:
In the 2004 movie "The Village" by celebrated director M. Night Shyamalan, we find a parallel for how the LDS Church leaders have kept the REAL truth of Mormonism hidden from its members for almost 200 years. 

**SPOILERS**

Kirsten of @Cashual.advice  and Megan of @Third_Verse dive into the cautionary tale about a group of people, traumatized by the cruelty of modern life, driven to create an isolated community with the shared goal of protecting one another. In an effort to make sure nobody leaves the village into the outside world, they create a shared mythology around the threat of devouring monsters, only to find that the solution to the problem they were trying to solve created a whole new set of problems. **Kindof like Joseph Smith and the Founders of Mormonism did with religion. **

    •    2 oz bourbon
    •    ¾ oz lemon juice
    •    ½ oz honey syrup
    •    Dash of Angostura bitters
Garnish: Orange peel twist + edible gold dust (optional)
A toast to new beginnings in a new land!

episodes.title: LIVE Family Night! Nephi's Brothers Beat Him Up
episodes.description:
In the Book of Mormon, Nephi and his family cross the ocean in a boat Nephi made with his bare hands. Not surprisingly, his older brothers get mad at him when they get lost and try to beat him up. 

Join us for Treats, Tea and Snark! 

Tonight's Treat: 

The Ocean's Liahona
A smooth, blue-green
cocktail inspired by calm seas.

INGREDIENTS
• 1 oz vodka
• 1 oz coconut rum
• 2 oz blue curaçao
• 2 oz lemonade
• 1 oz coconut water

INSTRUCTIONS
1. Shake everything with ice.
2. Strain into a chilled glass.
3. Garnish with a lemon twist or a small mint sprig.

episodes.title: What Do Mormons Have to Answer Before Baptism?
episodes.description:
Join Kirsten and Megan Conner as they discuss the interview questions asked prior to baptism! Even 8 year old kids have to pass an interview before they get Baptized into the Mormon Church. All of the questions essentially point to the same things: Do you believe,  will you follow the rules, and will you be loyal to the church. NOT Jesus... the CHURCH. lol

episodes.title: How We Got Baptized into the Mormon Church
episodes.description:
Megan Conner and Kirsten talk about their experience being baptized into the mormon church at the age of 8. They share how they feel the indoctrination they received in their mormon families made it so that Baptism was not really a choice, but an expectation of their families, and how the experience shaped their lives.

episodes.title: Revealing the Joseph Smith Biography that changed it all!
episodes.description:
"No Man Knows My History" - the groundbreaking biography of self-proclaimed Mormon Prophet Joseph Smith, published in 1944, reveals deeply personal insights into the founder of the LDS church. Megan Conner shares what she's learned with Kirsten, who has never read the controversial book! 

As always, this duo handles the hard truth with wit, humor, and a healthy dose of snark!
